misconceptions.name: Misinterpreting the problem requirements
misconceptions.description: The student implemented an average acceleration calculator instead of a program that reads 5 integers and sums only the even numbers.
misconceptions.student_belief: The task is to read initial and final velocities and time, then compute and print the average acceleration using (v1 - v0) / t.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The task is to read exactly 5 integers from the user, identify which of them are even (n % 2 == 0), accumulate the sum of those even numbers, and then print that sum.
symptoms: Prompt asks for v0, v1, and t instead of 5 integers
Program reads three doubles instead of five integers
No loop is used to process five values
No conditional check for even numbers (n % 2 == 0)
Program computes (v1 - v0) / t and prints an acceleration message instead of summing even numbers
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion with a different exercise (average acceleration) or not carefully reading the current problem statement.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement and rewrite the program so that it follows each requirement: read 5 integers, loop over them, check for even numbers using n % 2 == 0, keep a running sum of even values, and print that sum.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Every part of the program (prompt, variable names, formula, and output message) corresponds to an acceleration problem, not to summing even numbers.

evidence.note: The entire interaction and computation is about velocities, time, and acceleration, with three doubles read, not five integers, and no summing of even numbers.

misconceptions.name: Misunderstanding the Assignment Prompt
misconceptions.description: The student submitted a solution for a different problem (calculating average acceleration) instead of the required task (finding the sum of 5 even numbers). The code fails to meet any criteria of the rubric for Q1.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes the provided code, which calculates acceleration, satisfies the requirements for Question 1.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires reading 5 integers and summing only the even ones, utilizing a loop and conditional logic.
symptoms: The class is named 'AccelerationCalculator'
Reads 3 double inputs instead of 5 integer inputs
Calculates a = (v1 - v0) / t
No loop structure present
No modulo operator (for even check) or accumulator (for sum) present
misconceptions.root_cause: Misreading the assignment instruction, submitting the code for the wrong question, or potentially uploading the wrong file.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Please review the prompt for Q1: 'Sum of Even Numbers' carefully and submit the correct implementation. This problem requires input iteration, conditional logic using the modulo operator (%), and accumulation.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The student's code structure, input reading (3 doubles), and calculation logic (velocity difference over time) are irrefutably unrelated to the prompt (sum of 5 even integers).

evidence.note: The entire program is dedicated to calculating acceleration, demonstrating the student implemented the wrong assignment.

misconceptions.name: Misunderstanding of problem requirements
misconceptions.description: The student appears to have misunderstood the assignment. Instead of reading 5 integers and summing the even ones, the student wrote a program that reads 3 doubles (v0, v1, t) and calculates acceleration using the formula a = (v1 - v0) / t. This is a completely different problem.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe they were solving a physics acceleration problem rather than the stated 'Sum of Even Numbers' problem.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires reading exactly 5 integers from the user, checking which ones are even (divisible by 2), and printing their sum. For example: input '3 8 2 7 4' should output 'Sum of even numbers: 14' (because 8 + 2 + 4 = 14).
symptoms: Program reads 3 doubles instead of 5 integers
Program performs acceleration calculation instead of summing even numbers
Output message is about acceleration, not sum of even numbers
No loop structure to process multiple inputs
No even/odd checking logic present
misconceptions.root_cause: The student either read the wrong problem statement, copied code from a different assignment, or fundamentally misunderstood what was being asked.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully. The task is to: (1) Read 5 integers, (2) Check each for evenness using n % 2 == 0, (3) Sum only the even numbers, (4) Print the result. Use a loop (for or while) to process all 5 integers efficiently.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Extremely high confidence. The submitted code solves a completely different problem (acceleration calculation) with different input requirements, variable names, and output format. This is not a minor logic error but a fundamental mismatch with the assignment.

evidence.note: Code reads 3 doubles (v0, v1, t) for acceleration calculation, but assignment requires reading 5 integers for sum of evens

evidence.snippet:
double a = (v1 - v0) / t;

System.out.println("The average acceleration is " + a);
evidence.note: Code calculates acceleration (physics formula), not sum of even numbers. Output says 'acceleration', not 'sum of even numbers'
Class is named 'AccelerationCalculator', indicating this is the wrong problem entirely. Should be related to summing even numbers.

misconceptions.name: Misinterpreting the problem requirements
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a program to compute average acceleration from v0, v1, and t instead of reading 5 integers and computing the sum of the even ones, indicating a misunderstanding of what the assignment is asking for.
misconceptions.student_belief: The assignment is to write an acceleration calculator that reads v0, v1, and t and computes (v1 - v0) / t.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment is to read exactly 5 integers from the user, identify which of them are even (n % 2 == 0), and then print the sum of only those even numbers.
symptoms: Prompt asks for 'v0, v1, and t' instead of 5 integers.
Program reads three double values rather than five integers.
Code computes an acceleration formula (v1 - v0) / t instead of summing even numbers.
Output message describes 'average acceleration' instead of 'Sum of even numbers'.
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely misreading or not carefully following the problem specification, leading to solving a different textbook-style problem instead of the required even-number summation task.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the full problem statement slowly and identify the required inputs, processing steps, and outputs. Before coding, write down in plain language: (1) what needs to be read from the user, (2) what condition defines an 'even' number, and (3) how to accumulate and then print the sum. Then implement that algorithm step by step.
related_concepts: Using loops to process a fixed number of inputs
Using the modulus operator to test for even numbers
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Every aspect of the program (variable names, prompt text, formula, and output message) consistently targets an acceleration calculation rather than summing even numbers, showing a clear mismatch with the assignment requirements.

evidence.note: The code clearly implements an average acceleration calculator with inputs v0, v1, and t and outputs 'The average acceleration is ...', which does not match the requirement to read 5 integers and sum the even ones.

misconceptions.name: Complete Misunderstanding of Problem Requirement

misconceptions.confidence_rationale: High confidence. The student's code is a complete, working solution for an entirely different physics problem, demonstrating a total failure to address the stated assignment (Q1: Sum of Even Numbers).

misconceptions.name: Misinterpretation of Problem Requirements
misconceptions.description: The student has solved a completely different problem (calculating average acceleration) instead of the required task of reading 5 integers and summing only the even numbers. The student reads 3 doubles (v0, v1, t) and calculates physics-related values rather than processing the integers specified in the assignment.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe they should read three numeric inputs (v0, v1, t) and calculate average acceleration using the formula a = (v1 - v0) / t
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The task requires reading exactly 5 integers from the user, checking each one to see if it is even (divisible by 2), accumulating the sum of only the even numbers, and printing that sum.
symptoms: Program reads 3 doubles instead of 5 integers
Program calculates acceleration instead of sum of even numbers

misconceptions.root_cause: Student appears to have submitted code from an entirely different assignment (physics/kinematics problem) rather than solving the given sum-of-evens problem. This suggests either a copy-paste error from another assignment or fundamental confusion about the assignment requirements.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Carefully re-read the assignment requirements. You need to: (1) use a loop to read 5 integers, (2) use an if statement with condition (number % 2 == 0) to check if each number is even, (3) add even numbers to a sum variable, and (4) print the final sum.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Extremely high confidence. The submitted code solves a physics acceleration problem, not the sum-of-even-numbers problem. The variables (v0, v1, t), the calculation ((v1 - v0) / t), and the output message are all completely unrelated to the requirements. This is not a minor logic error—it is the wrong problem entirely.

System.out.println("The average acceleration is " + a);
